body.value:
And here Val Ward
is talking to one of the greatest
poets, one of the greatest writers.

Alive today and selfish
and honored to call you.

Also one of my best friends in the
world, but more importantly than
our personal friendship is what you
write, talk sense to the people.

I am a black woman, you know,
rising mass for inner city so much.

Always teaching and some other things that
people, other people don't know about you.

Some people probably think you just
lecture and teach at universities
that maybe Maria Evans does not
have children and grandchildren.

Maybe she's not, um,
doesn't do anything else.
But I also know you as an activist.

I, I see you as a complete poet, but
I haven't seen the autobiography.

Of all the anthologies
of all your own public.

What about Mari Evans speaking
for Mari Evans as opposed to
how the biographers see you?
Tell us a little bit about Mari Evans.

Well, I've resisted
doing an autobiography.

It, um, seems so grand to
do one's autobiography, you
know, and so I resisted it.
Uh, long time ago, Langston said to me.

Langston Hughes said,
um, to me, um, the prerequisite for
writing is to have something to say.

And, um, I had been writing maybe
eight or nine years when he said that.

And, uh, I went into shock because
I thought, oh my heavens, I've
been writing all this time.
Have I had anything to say?

Uh, that's how I feel
about an autobiography.
Uh, you know, what is there truly to say?

Because as you know, I'm a very,
very private person, which is why
I don't talk about my children.
I don't talk about their children.

There's so much that I don't talk
about, and yet I will say that, um,
I have uh, experienced all the things
that African Americans experienced.

You know, uh, I'm part and
parcel of the whole, a small
part and parcel of the whole.

And, um, uh, sometimes it seems a little
redundant to say some of the stuff.

So anyhow, I've been fighting with
the idea of an autobiography, but
finally, um, I've decided that, um.

I, in addition to writing poetry,
um, I've tried all the other genres.
I've, I have a number of performed pieces.

You know, I know you're a playwright,
you're a musician, tennis player.

I, I, I compose music and, uh,
I've done about 17 songs for one
musical words in music, and, um.

Um, I call my theater pieces, theater
pieces not plays because I don't play,
you know, and, uh, uh, we should be about

something and to say I write plays to
me is diminishing the work, you know?

So I do theater pieces and um, I do
political articles and, uh, someone
came up to me last night and said.
I don't know anything about you.

Someone ask you, Marie Evans, have
you ever had anything published?

And I said, sister,
I've only been in town about an
hour gimme time to come down.

But, uh, the, the thing that I find
fascinating is what, the things I write
that I think I'm most proud of are the

political articles and essays because,
um, poetry is an eclectic form in a sense.

And, um, uh, you don't, you cover a
lot of the bases and if you're lucky,
you may cover most of them, you know,
but an article or theater piece, uh.

And, uh, you mentioned
speak the truth to the people.

And at this time of
crisis in our national life, um, we
can use a, a more extensive forum.
And so I do political pieces.

And, um, one of the things I
wanted to mention today, because.

You were going to, uh, ask me
some things about poetry and all,
and I said, oh, I really wanna
talk about some political things.

And, um, I thought in line with
speaking the truth, which you mentioned,
that poem, uh, that poem tells us to
speak the truth to the people, but it

takes an article for me to say some
of that truth, you know, and Brother
Haki, uh, pulled together a book.

Uh, after South Central occurred,
the riots, of course, in, uh, I
have to explain this may place.

This is first
world, uh, press in Chicago, right?

Uh, this may play 20 years from now when
South Central will have been forgotten,
but, but, um, uh, the riots that happened
in South Central, um, as a result of, um.

The Rodney King trials
and verdict and, uh,

And he, he wanted some of us to give, to
give him pieces, and I gave him one, and
mine was entitled, simply South Central.

Um, when I thought about South Central
and I thought about the efforts that
were made by persons of high visibility

throughout the country, who would go
to South Central and pull some of the
people in South Central together and

sit them down and that, and I thought,
and people would, people all over the
country saying, why, why did this happen?
And I, and I kept thinking.
And you said why not before now.
How did you keep the lid on?

Well, yeah, and I said, let
me talk some sense about South Central.

And one of the things that I
began with was the fact that our,
our, I need these was our, our
initial black white encounter.

It was adversarial from the
very beginning, from the outset.

It was adversarial, uh uh, and
we continued as combatants.

Physically and psychologically engaged
in what I call a grotesque party[?].

Do you know with, um, uh, uh, freedom
involuntarily paired with oppression?

And that has been the way of it,
um, uh, from the beginning, uh, uh,
adversarial relationship, those of us
who are black with those who are white.

From the outset psychologically and
physically, and, uh, uh, nothing
has changed because the dance, this

grotesque dance that the dancers are
doing, one white and one black always
involves, uh, opposing movement.

With one dancer pulling in one direction
and one resisting and pulling in the other
direction, nothing has been settled ever.

In 400 years, there has been
no, no closure brought to this.

Are you saying to me
with all of the poetry, the civil rights
movement with the various long before
now in Virginia, when Nat Turner and

Gabriel Pross and all these people, and
everybody did their little bit, where
ever it was the marching in the sixties.

So you, you, you made a statement,
you said, but there's still

the, the tension is
there and there has been no closure.
The dance is not over for us.

The people who went to South Central
forgot that it was not about love.

And I said, uh, in the words of Tina
Turner, what's love got to do with it?
What's love got to do with that?

And so the dance is this enormous
movement, uh, that the powerless
against those in power oppression,

against the determination toward
freedom and liberation, and until
the exercise of power is mutual.

And James Weldon Johnson said, and I
wish I had his, uh, the verbatim quote,
but he said something like, uh, history

holds no precedent of two nations of
equal power living together in harmony.

So that was another poet
saying, doing the same thing you're
doing now, say, I must write beyond

And, and what we have that, uh,
black people choose to ignore is
two nations of nearly equal power

each identifiable so that the
dance is quite clear cut, you know?

And, um, um, let me,
there's something here.

The oppressed and we are the oppressed
are crisis oriented, we can summon
a great cohesiveness in times of
extreme sadness or joy or trouble,

crisis oriented, great cohesiveness
in times of sadness or joy.

What is that
point in the, is it yours?
Are Gwen in the something time?

I know it's, I can't think of a word,
but I know I, I could see it right then.

We should always be,
prepare, preparing, always.

Working on this, but as you say,
we respond to crisis, right?

We respond when somebody get mad,
when Rodney Kings gets beaten.

As if people aren't
dying every day and so forth.

And, and that, uh, um, it is then that
we understand these times of trouble
that we understand, uh, on an acutely

I understand that the man or woman
next to me that we are a family nation
now, we deny that psychologically

and say, I'm neither white nor
black, or whatever, you know?

But in moments of extreme crisis,
we return to the source and
understand ourselves across the
board as a family nation and it.

Something capricious can strike off
that moment of crisis, you know?

But is it true we need
more than the response to the crisis?

What about, or if I call it the
wrong thing, I'll edit it out.

What about the war within
the war among black people?

There was a time when you and I
were growing up that an elder, an
older person, was just respected.

We used to say in Mississippi, you don't
even say a bad word In front of grown
people, you know, the community really

did rear a child because everybody,
anybody could say something to you.

I know we are living in a different
age, but now shootings, rapings killing.
Now I know some of the whys of that.

How is it that it's focused in
here, this inner  destruction,
and what can we do about it?

In the sixties and seventies and
eighties, Mari Evans could come to
Chicago and speak to a thousand people
because we could get them there.

But now the rappers, and again, I'm not
against rappers because Gwendolyn had
to say to me, Gwendolyn Brooks, Val, all
the rappers are not saying bad things.

And all the, at that time, we were
calling ourselves beautiful and
black and all these things, and now
women are calling themselves bitches.

And so they call themselves
that as rappers and so forth and
poets, and they seem to glorify
in some of this destruction.

Well, I will ask if it's art, but
isn't some of that poetry and why
the form in the sixties, young kids

were coming up behind you, a younger
writers trying to say what you're
saying, analyzing what you're saying.

And I'm saying now there's
another force it seems, and the
force is in inner destruction.

I think, um, um, if I try to tie in,
uh, the reflections you just, uh,
shared with, um, my whole sense of, of
ourself as a family nation who respond

to each other in crisis, um, one thing
that is quite clear to me in terms of
today's young society is that we do not

pull the variables in and come up with
a, um, concept that we can use as,
uh, um, as a kind of north star maybe.

Um, what, uh, in speaking the
truth to the people when, when
I write that in the beginning,
our relationship was adversarial.

That's a concept that somebody young
can take and trace right along to
now and understand more about what

is happening now than, than, than
they may have understood earlier.

And, uh, that there is no separation,
that the struggle alluded, continual
goes on, um, that until there's

some closure and until you say,
what can we do about it until we.

As the caregivers, the teachers,
the models, um, because each of
us who simply walks along the the
street is modeling until we can
start at the beginning to teach, um,

Uh, understanding concepts, building
concepts, like we can't live as
an oppressed people in a, um,

sporadic with, with our thoughts
and our directions sporadic.
We have to find the continuum.

We have to find the root of
what it is that is eating at us.

And I'm suggesting that the root for much
of what's happening is that there has been
no closure to our earlier, um, dance of

The two dancers, the, the, the
adversarial relationship between those
in power and those without power.
The poet, the teacher, the preacher.

It's, it's, it's, it's all
of ours to, to share truth as we see it.

Some of us can do it more simply
than others, and some of us
simply do it in a different arena.

The preacher does it insofar as
he can, or is, you know, uh, in
certain place, put it in another,
uh, the playwright, uh, I like.

Now, the problem with the political
article is everybody doesn't
read the political article,
and it's very difficult Yes.

You know, to, to find a medium
that reaches everybody, uh,
or that reaches enough people.

but I think because
you're Mari Evans, the poet, all of
these people, the playwright, the
musician, uh, people will be all of us.

Not just the reading audience, but those
of us like me who feel that I'm a voice
for people who don't read and what a
voice and what a voice, a reo[?] For

our people, for the continuity of that
north star, of that negro spiritual of
the wonderful things that you give us.

People like me wouldn't exist
if you didn't give us that
and even make us feel as that.

How do we pass that confirmation that
you write about in the prose, in the,
in these political pieces in the place?
How at one time it was more powerful?

We, we have, uh, I think
I would go back to the fact that we
boil things down to concept and we have
to, there have been no battles won.
I mean, no, no, no wars won.

There's been a battle
here, a battle there.

Uh, people say you, you people
have made progress and, you
know, and, and, and my own,

I hear poets here
saying, I am now teaching at, I
shouldn't name schools, but this is
hypothetical Vassar, I'm at Smith Sure.

Or I have the political, uh, the
Pulitzer Prize, or I'm, I'm just naming.
Or, Tony won the Nobel Prize.

How close are we to, to
liberation or does it matter?

I think that's
what you're saying, right?

And I'm saying until we, uh, zero
in on the basic concept, we can't
approach a solution because we don't
understand what kind of war we're in.

I know that this does
not, um, close out your teaching
and my trying to carry on the work

and others, but if we can close
this interview until we, while we.

Await the by autobiography of
Mari Evans, which is in the works.

We would just like you to
close with a few lines.
Sum up what we've talked about.

Um, it's, it's difficult,
uh, 'cause I don't know, and I know
so few of my own, own pieces by heart.

Uh, the only line I can think of that
encompasses all of us in the, the,
the tremendous togetherness we feel,
particularly here at the conference

and we talked about, um, um, coming
together in times of crisis and, and
in sadness and in joy, in trouble.

And I would say who can be
born black and not exalt.

Any case,
we're here at Furious Flower.
Uh, it's a gathering of poets.

It's a both a scholarly conference and
a celebration of poetry in that there
are, ooh, a number of poets who are here.

There are a number who are not
here, but there's probably the
largest gathering of, uh, African
American poets in a number of years.

I don't recall a conference, this
representative since, um, Howard in
75 and the Houston Baker Confab at the

University of Pennsylvania with Holy
Soka [?] And Braith Wayton [?] And mm-hmm.
And, uh, nearly everybody, you know?

Interesting things about this conference
and, and contradistinction to some
of the others, is that the focus is
entirely on African American poetry.

In the
context of doing poetry.

Many of us have been writing for oh
years now, uh, often writing regionally
and often writing outside of the

academic, uh, networks and outside
of the commercial publishing houses.

Everett, I'd like you to tell us a
little bit about your career, how
you got started writing, and where
your work is published, et cetera.

I, um, I began writing verse to, uh,
reward my mother for wonderful dinners.

As you can tell by looking at
me, I've always enjoyed eating.

Um, but I began to identify myself
as a poet at Lincoln University.

Where in my senior year, Langston
Hughes was good enough and generous
enough characteristically to sit

down and spend some time with
me when he visited the campus.

Um, I began to publish, uh, at the
national level first, uh, through
Clarence Majors, the New Black

Poetry, and, um, thereafter began to
identify myself as a poet who taught.

Um, I went to, uh, the graduate
writing program at Brown and
studied under Michael Harper.

Um, I was fortunate to be there with,
um Andrew Seal [?] And, uh, Gail Jones.

And Melvin Dixon, we were
all in the same class.

Um, we were, I think the first
black graduate writing students
at Brown in that program.

And, um, began to, uh, actually I
published before then I published in
the Black Poets because I was one of
the, uh, the Broadside Press posts.

Um, my humble chapbook being, I think,
uh, the first, uh, collection of erotic
black love poetry published by an African

American, uh, period, uh, was exerted very
kindly by Dudley Randall in this book.
Uh, recently my work has appeared in, um.

Uh, journals mainly, uh, like the
American Poetry Review, uh, World
Magazine, uh, et cetera, et cetera.

But I've been in
anthologies, uh, in between.

A chap book has come out, uh, came
out in the seventies and I have a book
manuscript entitled ...Here, with an

ellipsis before the Word and afterward,
HERE, um, that, um, uh, will be considered
for, is being considered for publication.

Why don't
you read a selection for us?

Actually, um, the
poem I wanted to, uh, I would like to
share, uh, that has to do with a man
who came from Virginia, happened to

be my great-grandfather, uh, William
David Holmes, who was, um, one of
six sons, uh, sired, not fathered.

He wasn't a father by a
plantation master in Virginia.

And my great-grandfather went into the
Civil War as a Union army soldier in
order to get a gun to kill his father

because, um, the way his father had abused
his mother, he would not set her free.

Uh, he, unlike his brothers, did not
pass for white, and he married an African
woman, my maternal grandmother's mother.

Um, that poem is in the May, June issue
of the American Poetry Review, which I
have loaned to someone at this conference
and unfortunately do not have with me.
But, um, it's a very powerful story.

Uh, instead I'd like to recite a poem
that, uh, is about us in the sense of,
uh, Guffer[?] and VeVe[?] and, uh, what

we come from and what we go to after
this particular plane of existence.

It's a response to Edward
Brathwaite’s, poem, Pebble.

Rock is the placenta of time,
but rock can be shattered.
The hammer does not destroy it.

It will not make good
statues of your heroes.
Heroes are made of of it.
It cannot be slung or thrown.

Explosives never destroy
primitive, but it can kill you.
Tell us about how you go about writing.

For instance, that poem, um,
it's rich in metaphor, but it's
also quote unquote very simple.

Um, there's a simplicity to it and there's
a also obviously a complexity to it.

You know, I don't, uh,
I, as Michael Harper taught me, you know,
I, I'm wary of poets who, uh, explain,
uh, how, why they do what they do.

All I know is I was
proctoring a, a final examination.

My students were taking the test
and I picked up a piece of chalk
and I contemplated the dust.

And on the cover of a blue book, I did
the first draft of that and it went
through three drafts and that was it.

Um, you see there's something
in the dictionary called cosmic
dust, and I sometimes just go
read the dictionary, you know?
And cosmic dust is the stuff of creation.

The ashes of
gases that eventually congeal into
a sphere and become planets and.

And from those planets,
life forms, uh, uh, develop.

And what changes
did you make between the first
draft and the, and the final?

Uh, basically, uh,
line placement, um, uh, enjambment,
uh, modifications and diction.

Uh, that's about it that
came almost spontaneously.

Uh, because I had been teaching
Edward Brathwaite’s poem Pebble.

And I
sent him a copy of this.

And in the original publication
of this poem and on the Iowa
Review, uh, it's noted that it's
dedicated to Edward Brathwaite.

And he, uh, wrote
back and thanked me and said, from
the University of West Indies.

And, uh, said, uh, uh, I think, uh,
truly that, uh, the poem was, uh, in
his estimation better than Pebble.
That's, that's a very cryptic piece.

Tell me
something about you, man.
Tell me about, uh, what is life?
I'm from the deep South New Orleans.

Um, Langston Hughes was the person that
got me started writing in eighth grade.

An English teacher, played a
recording of Langton Hughes.

I went straight to the
library that afternoon.

Checked out all the Langston Hughes
I could find and never looked back.

It was, and Langton Hughes was both my
guide in terms of how to write, what to
write and, and, and the genres of writing.

And he was also, um, an inspiration
and, um, and a teacher in
terms of what, what to read.

So I started
reading his autobiographies and
every writer he mentioned, I went
to the library and checked them out.

And needless to say, what ended up
happening was that I got a thorough
education by the time I was out of
high school in world literature.

following all the writers he mentioned,
but by then I had not only read the
Harlem Renaissance and, uh, many of the
writers, um, the, uh, uh, American writers

who are out of favor in some, uh, survey
courses today, such as John de Apostles
and Rachel Lindsay and so forth and so on.

Had the opportunity to read Russian
writers, Chinese writers, Japanese
writers, African writers, South American

writers, Central American Caribbean
writers as a result of Langston Hughes.

So after that, I didn't, my, my
reading, uh, was dictated much more
by my, uh, social and political
concerns than by my literary concerns.
And I'd had my basic foundation.

I, I like to say was in
non-European world literature.

So actually, you know,
whereas, um, I could not say that I had,
uh, read, um, let's say I, I have not
read all of, um, I haven't read Virginia

Wolf, but I read Bloke Mandasein[?] you
see, I hadn't, uh, I, I had not read
all of Faulkner just a very little bit.

And,
and I knew Arif Domo[?].

So that was, uh, Langton
Hughes got me started.

And, and then after that, um,
I'm in the army, out of the army.

And in 1968 I returned to New Orleans from
the army, join the Free Southern Theater.

starts my career
professionally as a writer.

Up until that time I,
I was writing, um, you know, you might
give a poem to a friend or something,
or you sent little pieces out and, and

in fact, in '67 before I left the army,
I sent a collection of fiction to, um,
I think Phil Petri and someone else,
one at William and Morrow, one at Dow.

Uh, because that's where
Langston Hughes and.

Where also where, um, not Langton,
Leroy Jones at the time Yeah.

Well, I
got to jam with you, man.

You know, you got, I got to jam with, uh,
I'm gonna do a thing for, uh, out a love
child, Uhhuh that is published in here.

The first part of which goes like
this Sweet bake apple dappled cinnamon
speckled cinnamon nut, meg freckle,
peach brandy and amber wine woman.

With your finger popping black
African pepper pot, not stopping
the coffee flowing, steaming,
creaming the brown sugar.
Gong crazy about brown sugar teases.
Good God and pleases sweet Jesus.

Slow molasses ass and hot damn candied
Yam and sweet potato pie thighs and sweet
raisin tipped coconut tits raising cane

sugar stone brown sugar
bowl belly to the bone.

That's what
you call, that's what you call
a politically incorrect poem.

Let, let
once, let them get on the bed

once, once you made
me holler worse than the time I got
shot in the leg with a 38 caliber.

And, and, and,
and, and when I thought of him
the ways his love would take of mine.

And drain his black iron, bronze of
moist fire of darkly essence nourishment.

All
right, now you're touch me.

Self made
many black poor, right?
All right, JHA, A long time ago.

I say, all you young
girls waiting to live.

I say, all you young
girls taking your pill.

I say, all your sister's
tired of standing still.

I say, all your sisters thinking
you won't, but you will.
Don't let them kill you with their stare.
Don't let them closet you with no air.
Don't let them feed you sex piece meal.
Don't let them offer you any ordeal.
No more hanging by a thread.
Can't let it all go unsaid too.

I say, all your young girls
giving it up again and again.

I say, all your sisters
hanging out and every day.

And I say, all your sisters
needing your own oxygen.
Don't let them trap you with their coke.

Don't let them treat
you like one fact joke.
Don't let them bleed you till you broke.

Don't let them blind
you in masculine smoke.
Just we rising from the dead.

I say step back, Johnny's,
we dancing on our heads.
No more hanging by a thread.
an't let it all go unsaid.
Can't let it all go unsaid.
For my, uh, women's studies class.

You know, we used to talk about
writing poetry and being new.
We said we were gonna change everything.

And um, I'm wondering is that, is that
new or is that something very, very old?

Well, I think that
the whole point is that when you
were as young as we were Yeah.

And we stepped out and said, I'm going
to do this new thing, and you say, yeah.

Lorenzo, we gonna do this new,
new, new, new, new thing you say?

Then we jumped out and did it
and all of a sudden we went
back and start reading Sterling.
You know, and they did something new.
That's what I'm trying to say, you know?
And then we said, well, yeah, right.
We read Gwen, we said Red Margaret.
He said, yes, I love him, I love him.

And we said, well, they
were doing that too.

So the newness is that
we're doing it in our time.

The newness is that we are
saying in with our own words.

You know, for our time
and for a future time.

Also too, the newness is that
we're saying it to a new audience,
you know, and a newer audience.

Um, but the point is that the real
newness is that we finally find out
that we are part of a tradition, right.

It says something when I
said something very old.
And it says something that's true.

And it is, it's a, it
points people to truth.

Uh, which is something
else that, uh mm-hmm.
Coming up in the sixties and mm-hmm.

Uh, you know, looking to
those that came for us.

Um, not only the Harlem
Renaissance that we read about

But the people that
we could actually meet and know people
like Langston Hughes, Langton, people
like Gwendolyn Brooks and Ms. Brooks.
All of whom connected us to a tradition.

I mean all, he
was just a little bit later,
but just step Jimmy, you know?

You know, when I teach my African-American
Lit class and I think back, and, I
mean, I've had students and when I
taught my lit class, everyone was alive.

Well, Richard Wright was
the only one not alive.

You know, and also Malcolm and
I taught Malcolm's book too,
but I mean, Ellison was alive.
Do you know what I'm saying?

And a whole bunch of other
people too, were in quote, alive.

And now I go in and teach that class, and
we start off with Wright Dead, you know?
Uh, Ellison Dead, um, um, Jimmy Dead.
You know, it, it, it removes you.

From this arena of saying simply
as we had talked about before,
they were people that, that we
used to read and look up to, right?

And they were there
occupying a sacred place.

Now Lorenzo, you know, all of
us, uh, Gwen is already in,
in the sense of sacred place.
And I don't mean that, uh, that we.

We think people are wholly
not to be understood.

I mean, she's wholly in the
sense that she is whole.
